Dear Ms. Gaskew:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents’ needs, implementation of treatment plans,
and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has not received proper mental health provisions,
including mismanagement of medications by the facility.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 12/06/2023 over the phone
and no additional information was provided.
Youth A was interviewed on 11/30/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to her school. Youth A
recalled what she could about the medication that she took at that
time. She stated she was provided medication in the a.m. before
school and in the p.m. before bedtime. She stated there are eight
or nine medications that she took in the evenings and that
sometimes they made her feel sick. Youth A believed that there
were some medications that she does not have, but she did not
know why she did not have them. Youth A stated she had gone to
the doctor on 11/29/2023 in order to address any other needed
medication. Youth A stated she had come to the program with
medications and that only recently were there some change or
missing medications.
Email communication occurred between Youth A’s Foster Care
case manager and DHHS Worker 1 on 11/30/2023. Youth A’s
Foster Care case manager stated she had been aware of the
lapses in medications at the beginning of Youth A’s placement at
the program as well as more recently. She stated there was an
interruption in her medication over the Thanksgiving holiday due
to a supply issue at the local pharmacy used by the program, but
this medication was procured as of 11/27/2023. Foster Care case
manager stated she had received communication from the
program over the course of the placement and had worked
collaboratively on any medication and prescription concerns.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 12/05/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Staff 1
stated she was aware there have been difficulties in procuring all
2

the medication for Youth A during her time placed at the facility.
Staff 1 believed there was one or two occasions during Youth A’s
placement when a visit to the hospital during a crisis resulted in a
medication change on top of what she had already been
prescribed by her home physician from another county. Staff 1
stated the medication had all been consistent until about a month
ago. In addition, the facility had been working with the local
hospital that Youth A had visited on multiple occasions in order to
address concerns from the hospital that some of the medication
Youth A was prescribed was not necessary. Staff 1 provided
detailed occasions when Youth A had to go without medication
because the local pharmacy the program uses was out of stock for
those medications.
Documents reviewed:
• Medication Administration Records for Youth A from the
time of her placement in the program were reviewed. In
November 2023, there was one day, (11/15/2023), where it
was not documented that Youth A received her prescribed
medications, but this date matched with her presence at a
local hospital and absence from the program.
Analysis Through interviews of youth, staff and others as well as
documentation reviewed, there was no evidence found that
sufficient efforts were not occurring to provide medications as
prescribed to Youth A.
Consultation provided:
• The facility should put more effort in to locating and
partnering with a prescribing physician and pharmacy in the
area that can respond to the nature of sudden placements
in the shelter setting and the need for quick turnaround for
medications.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has been touched inappropriately by Youth B and this
was caused by a lack of supervision of staff.
3

Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 11/30/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to her school. She
stated there had been inappropriate touching going on between
her and another youth placed at the program. Youth A stated
Youth B had been touching her and laying on top of her. Youth A
noted this happened on several occasions, and that one notable
time was when she and Youth B were in another youth’s room.
Youth A stated this was the last time that inappropriate touching
had occurred. Youth A clarified that she and Youth B were
upstairs and that there were no staff upstairs with them, but that
staff were downstairs. Youth A believed this had occurred during
an evening either on Thanksgiving day or during that
Thanksgiving weekend. She stated she had not told staff at the
program because she was scared to. Youth A then stated she did
tell Chief Administrator and Staff 2. Youth A recalled she was
sitting on the bed of Youth D in another bedroom because she
was sad that this other youth was not at the program anymore.
Youth A stated she was initially alone in the room. Youth A
recalled that Youth B came into the room and sat on the bed and
then laid on top of Youth A without Youth A asking her to do so.
Youth A recalled that Youth B moved her hands near Youth A’s
breast and lower leg. Youth A stated Youth B then got up and sat
on the bed next to her. Youth A stated she was scared to tell
Youth B to stop. Youth A recalled that she then left the room about
10 minutes later. Youth A noted that Staff 1 and Staff 2 were
acting as one on one staff for her during this time. Youth A
detailed that there were other times that Youth B had touched her
while they were both placed at the program, but that the incident
in another Youth D’s room was the only time she felt unsafe or
unwarranted.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2023
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. Youth B
was aware of the allegations that involved her touching Youth A
inappropriately. She stated she has touched Youth A during their
time placed at the program, but never inappropriately. Youth B
stated Youth A liked head rubs and that Youth B had played with
Youth A’s hair when they were sitting next to each other on the
couch. She stated she has never touched Youth A when staff
were not around. Youth B stated there is now a rule that she
cannot be around Youth A because Youth A said that Youth B had
laid on her. Youth B stated she has never been in a room together
with Youth A without staff. Youth B then stated that there was one
occasion recently when she encountered Youth A in Youth D’s
room alone and went and sat with her. Youth D was no longer
placed at the facility at that time. She stated that Youth A was
4

sitting “criss cross applesauce” on Youth D’s bed, and that Youth
B came in and gave her a hug and then left. She believed this
occurred on one night over Thanksgiving weekend, and it was
after bedtime. Youth B believed that Staff 1 was the staff that was
upstairs, but that she was in another room and did not see Youth
A or Youth B. Youth B recalled that this was a short interaction,
and that Youth A never asked her to stop.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 12/05/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Staff 1
stated she has interacted with both Youth A and Youth B together
during their time placed in the program. She also stated that she
has served as the one on one staff for both youth. Staff 1 stated
there has not been a time when there was an instance of Youth A
or Youth B touching each other inappropriately when she was the
one on one staff, or when she was acting as the night staff while
the youth were supposed to be sleeping. Staff 1 stated there have
been many occasions when staff had instructed either Youth A or
Youth B to sit away from each other or to stop touching each
other, but these had all occurred during waking hours.
Youth C was interviewed during an announced, face-to-face visit
at the facility on 12/05/2023 with DHHS Worker 1. Youth C stated
that she has seen Youth A and Youth B touch each other and
described them as being “too touchy,” but she was not aware of
any situations where this occurred inappropriately or outside of
staff supervision.
Staff 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2023
during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Staff 2
stated that she had heard about the allegations from Youth A that
Youth B had touched her but did not know when or where this
may have occurred. Staff 2 stated she has never seen
inappropriatecontact between Youth A and Youth B.
Chief Administrator was interviewed on 12/15/2023 with DHHS
Worker 1 over video conference. She stated she was aware of the
allegations between Youth A and Youth B because Youth A had
made her aware of them over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend.
The Chief Administrator described a conversation with Youth A
that included details of the alleged incident that were consistent
with what Youth A provided. The Chief Administrator stated after
her conversation with Youth A, Youth A told everyone in the house
the same allegations later in the afternoon when Youth B was not
present. Chief Administrator recalled Youth A stating that was her
opinion that this had occurred because staff were not supervising
5

correctly. Youth A elaborated to the Chief Administrator that staff
were in the other room and not aware of where the youth were in
the upstairs bedrooms. Chief Administrator stated Youth A was
not able to pinpoint a specific day, time or staff that would have
been responsible at that time this alleged incident occurred. Chief
Administrator confirmed Youth A had been assigned a one on one
staff for the majority of the time placed at the program, far before
the time of the alleged incident, but could not state who this staff
member would have been without proper documentation or a date
to pinpoint when it occurred. The Chief Administrator believed that
all staff were well aware of this situation but stated that there were
no written documents regarding safety planning in response to the
situation despite everyone agreeing that Youth A and Youth B
needed to stay apart from each other.
Licensee Designee was interviewed on 12/15/2023 over video
conference with DHHS Worker 1. Licensee Designee stated that
she believed Staff 1 was on shift when the alleged incident
between Youth B and Youth A had occurred. Licensee Designee
believed that Youth A had later told a staff member, she could not
remember who, that she had lied about the incident with Youth B
to get Youth B in trouble. Licensee Designee stated that Youth A
should have had one on one supervision during the time that the
incident occurred, but she could not say who this staff would have
been.
Documentation reviewed:
• Documentation from the foster care case record of Youth A
was reviewed. Approval for 16 hours per day of One-to-
one supervision provided by the program directly with
Youth A and Youth B separately was authorized as of
08/30/2023 and 10/18/2023 respectively and continued for
the duration of their placements.
• A section of the overall policies & procedures from the
facility titled “Care & Safety” was reviewed. This policy
stated that “The primary job of all staff is to maintain
adequate coverage and line of sight of all youth at all times.
This means that youth are never left unattended for any
amount of time so that behaviors are supervised. HOLA will
have two staff members maintain line of sight during wake
hours.”
• There was not clear documentation able to be provided by
the agency regarding the specific staff who were acting as
the enhanced supervision for either Youth A or Youth B on
any given date or time.
6

• Security camera footage spanning the dates of 11/22/2023
through 11/26/2023 specifically of the upstairs hallway was
viewed. This camera captures the entryways of all the
youth’s bedrooms in the facility. Footage for this timespan
only included twenty second clips and not a continuous
timeframe. In addition, exact times of each clip could not
be identified. In the available video footage, there was not
a moment found that showed Youth A and Youth B entering
the same room that could have approximated the alleged
incident. The video footage showed some youth coming
and going from bedrooms and staff generally nearby but
included occasions that staff would not have been able to
have continuous line of sight view of the youth. No one was
ever in view long enough to determine their level of
supervision.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed, evidence was found that supervision was not provided
for Youth A or Youth B to the level stated in facility policy and
agreed upon with their respective case management, resulting in
the alleged incident in question not being able to be confirmed by
a staff member supervising either youth.
Technical Assistance provided:
• Clear and consistent documentation of who is providing
enhanced supervision for a youth at any given time is
something the facility will need to design and implement.
Consultation provided:
• Ease of access and familiarity with the facility’s chosen
security camera system would be of benefit in order to
more quickly and easily provide video footage when
needed as well as to review video footage of incidents for
coaching and training.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms
of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative
references to a youth’s background or appearance
7

or mental state. Yelling, threats, ridicule, or
humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has experienced negative and inappropriate comments
made to her by staff.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 11/30/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to her school. Youth A
alleged that staff members at the program say inappropriate
things to her. She stated Staff 1 has said the following statements
“no one loves you”, “shut the fuck up”, that her grandmother hates
her, that no one will ever adopt her, and commenting that Youth A
is fat. Youth A stated Staff 1 just that morning had said in the car
to her that “there’s no cameras in here, so I can say what I want.”
Youth A believed that it was only her and Staff 1 in the car, when
this occurred, and could not recall details of when Staff 1 stated
any of the other comments to her.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2023
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. Youth B
stated there are staff that have said inappropriate things to her
including “I’ll put you in jail” and “I’ll call the police.” Youth B could
not state which staff specifically said these things.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 12/05/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Staff 1
recalled a recent time when she had transported Youth A to
school to only have to go back to school to pick her up because
Youth A was significantly dysregulated, and the school had asked
the program to come get her. Staff 1 stated there were many other
occasions that she had transported Youth A. Staff 1 denied ever
saying anything inappropriate or anything close to what Youth A
had quoted during Youth A’s time placed at the program.
Staff 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2023
during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Staff 2
denied ever saying anything inappropriate to any of the youth in
the program and stated that she has not heard Staff 1 say
anything inappropriate or close to what was quoted by Youth A
either.
Youth C was interviewed during an announced, face-to-face visit
at the facility on 12/05/2023 with DHHS Worker 1. Youth C stated
she has not heard Staff 1 say anything inappropriate towards any
of the other youth in the program, nor towards herself.
8

Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff there was no sufficient
evidence found that staff have used discriminatory language
toward youth in the program.
Technical Assistance provided:
• More training and focus on how to communicate with youth
in a trauma informed manner would benefit staff and likely
better build rapport with youth and reduce escalations and
incidents.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was hit in the foot by a crutch held by the Chief
Administrator.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 11/30/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to her school. Youth A
stated the Chief Administrator had hit her with a crutch on the
morning of this interview. Youth A recalled that she was in the
dining area of the home when the Chief Administrator walked by
while on crutches. Youth A stated the Chief Administrator said,
“excuse me” and then proceeded to hit Youth A in the foot with her
crutch. Youth A believed that Licensee Designee and Staff 1 were
present for this incident.
Chief Administrator was interviewed on 12/15/2023 with DHHS
Worker 1 over video conference. Chief Administrator recalled the
incident in question regarding Youth A and being hit with one of
Chief Administrator crutches. She stated Youth A was escalated
on the morning in question before all the youth went to school.
The Chief Administrator recalled staying in between Youth A and
the sliding door that goes between the dining area and the staff
office to prevent her from going inside the office. The Chief
Administrator stated her crutch bumped into Youth A’s foot
unintentionally. The Chief Administrator did not believe that there
was much force behind this contact between her crutch and Youth
A’s foot. The Chief Administrator recalled stating “I’m sorry” to
9

Youth A when this occurred. The Chief Administrator believed that
Licensee Designee was present and witnessed the incident. The
Chief Administrator recalled that there were no injuries to Youth A,
and that another staff member, she could not remember who,
stated to Youth A “that was an accident, you know that.”
Licensee Designee was interviewed on 12/15/2023 over video
conference with DHHS Worker 1. She stated she was present on
the day in question when there was an alleged physical contact
between the Chief Administrator and a crutch and Youth A.
Licensee Designee recalled hearing Youth A state that Chief
Administrator had “taken her crutch and smashed my toe” and “I
think she did it on purpose because she’s mad at me.” Licensee
Designee stated she did not see the exact moment in time when
this incident occurred, but believed there was no ill intent or any
physical injury to Youth A.
Documents reviewed:
• Video footage from the morning of 11/30/2023 was
reviewed. In this footage it was heard that Youth A was
accusing the Chief Administrator of hitting her with her
crutch. The Chief Administrator’s response was calm,
stating she did not hit Youth A with her crutch, and she had
no intent of hurting Youth A.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documents reviewed,
there was no evidence found that Chief Administrator hit Youth A
with her crutch in a malicious manner or caused injury.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality.
Section (1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy and
Description confidentiality and shall protect residents from exploitation.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth B has not been afforded proper privacy in her assigned
bedroom.
Investigation Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2023
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. She
stated a recent rule was put into place that she was not allowed to
have her bedroom door closed, and this provided her stress in that
she felt like she was not able to have the privacy that she needed.
In addition, Youth B stated concern that there was a security
camera recently installed in the hallway outside of her bedroom
door that she felt pointed directly into her bedroom. Youth B also
stated there is a closet inside of her bedroom that is used for
10

storage of program-wide items. Youth B stated Staff 2 had come
into her room while Youth B was getting dressed to access items
in that closet. This upset Youth B because she felt like her privacy
was violated.
Staff 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 12/05/2023
during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Staff 2
acknowledged that she had entered Youth B’s room that morning
but denied that this occurred when Youth B was changing her
clothes. Staff 2 stated there is a closet located inside that
bedroom where Youth B was residing, and that closet was used to
store various items for the whole program.
Documents reviewed:
• Footage of the security camera placed outside of Youth B’s
room was viewed and it was noted that it does not shoot
directly inside of the bedroom.
Analysis Through interviews of youth and staff and documentation
reviewed, there was not sufficient evidence found for a rule
violation.
Consultation provided:
• Reconsideration should be made to the use of a closet for
the storage of program items within a youth’s bedroom.
Ensuring the privacy and physical and emotional safety of
youth placed in the program should not be prioritized less
than ease of access or lack of storage space within the
building.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
11

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
